column1: The more widely accepted story came from a citizens' meeting about naming the town. Webber was said to prefer the name Hardscrabble (which was used to describe the soils in the region) and Bishop pushed for the name Phelps Center. George Coppedge
column2: representing new settlers from North Carolina
column3: wanted to name the community after Raleigh. Bishop broke the three-way tie by agreeing with Coppedge as long as the name was spelled properly for the region
column4: Rolla.With numerous settlers from the South
column5: many residents of Rolla leaned toward the Confederacy during the American Civil War and the town was taken by Union forces in June 1861. They built two minor forts — Fort Wyman and Fort Dette — during their occupation.  Rolla was also the location of Camp Glover and Camp Davies.  From 1863 to 1865
column6: Rolla was the regimental headquarters of the 5th Missouri State Militia.For most of its history
column7: Rolla has served as a transportation and trading center. It was the original terminus of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway
column8: colloquially known as the "Frisco Line". Today
column9: the BNSF Railway directly runs through the town.

column1: Rolla was also a regular stop along U.S. Route 66

column1: Rolla is located at 37°56′56″N 91°45′47″W. According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 11.85 square miles (30.69 km2)
column3: of which 11.83 square miles (30.64 km2) is land and 0.02 square miles (0.05 km2) is water. Running through the city is the divide line that separates the vast Missouri watershed (via the Little Piney and the Gasconade) from the substantially smaller Meremec watershed (via the Bourbeuse).

column1: Rolla has a humid subtropical climate. The Köppen Climate Classification subtype for this climate is "Cfa".

column1: Rolla is home of the Rolla Bulldogs at Rolla High School.
Rolla is an important center for state and federal education and research in science and technology. It is the home of the Missouri University of Science and Technology (S&T or Missouri S&T)
column2: founded as the Missouri School of Mines and Metallurgy in 1870 and known as the University of Missouri–Rolla {UMR} from 1964 through 2007. Missouri S&T
column4: is well known for its engineering and computer science departments. In addition
column5: the US Geological Survey operates a large regional facility with various centers:  the National Geospatial Technical Operations Center III

column9: and the Rolla Science Information and Library Services office.
